ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Yes--I would absolutely recommend the course to another student in the department, and I have done so. It functions more like a reading group in which students prepare for the class and then take turn reading sections. As I suggested before, it is more like a reading group than a high-pressure course.

An ideal class for solidifying one's knowledge of Old English, and very helpful in moving from an elementary to a proficient level in reading the language. But also, a marvelous literature class in its own right, allowing for the exploration of religion, paleography, history, and more. The highest recommendation indeed.
You read the entirety of Beowulf in the original Old English; it's a challenging workload, but quite rewarding.
If you're interested in Beowulf, then you should absolutely take it. It's a wonderful course, and you will learn a lot. If you're not interested, then it isn't worth it.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: Roberta is cognizant of the ways the field changes in both faculty and research, and is constantly suggesting new authors or papers that we might read.
